text:
Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name (Mrs. Frank Davis)
Address: Wawota, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: Water, Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1896
Where did you set up housekeeping? Glen Adelaid, District
Where had you been living before that? Manitoba and Dakota
For how many people did you prepare meals? Six people
How far was it to your nearest store? Nine miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Baking powder, Baking Soda, Sugar flour, Tea & Coffee, Black pepper, Salt, Prime & dried Pepper.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? This flour was ground in Cannington Manor Mill from our own wheat
In what quantities did you buy it? Six or seven bag ground at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.90
How much did you use graham flour? 50¢ worth about 2 lbs
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 3 miles
That year? 1918
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 50¢
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1. **RECENTLY USING**

   - What year did you start school? 1896
   - Where did you go to high school?
   - How far did you travel before that?
   - For how many years did you live there?
   - How far was it to your nearest store?
   - How often could a visit be made to the store?

   *Baking Powder Baking Soda Cinnamon Sugar Bread Flour Pepper Salt*

2. **FLOUR AND OTHER FOODS**

   - In what quantity did you buy flour?
   - How much did you pay for flour?
   - Whole wheat flour?
   - Was flour milled locally?
   - Was the price for a twenty-pound barrel of rice?
   - Other grain products did you use?
   - Corn meal?
   - Other?
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
   - How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 259 words.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.64.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? [Handwritten text not legible]

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? [Handwritten text not legible]

At what price? [Handwritten text not legible]

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? [Handwritten text not legible]

Butter? [Handwritten text not legible] Eggs? [Handwritten text not legible]

What was the price of butter? [Handwritten text not legible] Or eggs? [Handwritten text not legible]

Did you keep eggs for winter? [Handwritten text not legible]

Did you make butter? [Handwritten text not legible] Cheese? [Handwritten text not legible]

What kind of cheese? [Handwritten text not legible]

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? [Handwritten text not legible]

How did you get fresh meat? [Handwritten text not legible]

How often did you get fresh meat? [Handwritten text not legible]

How did you preserve meat? [Handwritten text not legible]

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? [Handwritten text not legible]

If so what year was it organized? [Handwritten text not legible]

Did you use game? [Handwritten text not legible] What kinds? [Handwritten text not legible]

For how long? [Handwritten text not legible]

What part did fish play in the family diet? [Handwritten text not legible]

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? [Handwritten text not legible]

Kinds? [Handwritten text not legible]
3. IN WHAT QUANTITY DID YOU BUY BUTTER?

That was the price for a ten pound box of butter. Number 8.

What brand of butter did you buy? Number 9.

What size or size of butter did you usually buy? Number 10.

Did you prefer any particular brand or type of butter? Number 11.

4. MILK AND DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get fresh milk in the past? Number 12.

Butter? Number 13.

That was the price of butter. Number 14.

Did you purchase eggs for interest? Number 15.

Did you raise chickens? Number 16.

Did you raise cows? Number 17.

What kind of cheese did you make? Number 18.

5. MEAT AND FRESH PRODUCE

What was your meat supply in the past? Number 19.

How did you get fresh meat? Number 20.

How often did you get fresh meat? Number 21.

How did you preserve meat? Number 22.

Was there a "meat ring" in town? Number 23.

If so what year was it organized? Number 24.

Did you use farms? Number 25.

For how long? Number 26.

Did you raise animals? Number 27.

What part did they play in the family diet? Number 28.

Was the fish fresh, canned, or smoked? Number 29.

Kind of fish? Number 30.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black At what price? 40¢
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Green beans
Price? P.C.I.R.C. What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢/bus
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1897 Cabbage 1897 Carrots 1897 Onions 1897
Turnips 1897 Beets 1897

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? grew a few
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? in the bulk
What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
What was the price of prunes?
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? peas? Yes corn? beans? Saskatoons? other foods? pumpkins

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1926
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1916
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1906
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
To what extent? practically all
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes
6. Buy goods:
   - What kind of tea did you buy? (Tea)
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (Coffee)
   - Other (Specify)

7. Vegetables and dried fruits:
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel at the time?
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter off?
   - How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box?)
   - What weight?
   - How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
   - What other dried fruit did you use in the earliest days? (Apricots, prunes, apricots, peaches, longanberries, raisins, currants, etc.)

8. Preserving:
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by boiling?
   - Peas?
   - Corn?
   - Beans?
   - Other food?
   - This year did you first preserve fruit by canning?
   - This year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

To what extent did you make your own preserves?

Did you make your own vinegar?
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| Food                  | Year First Remember Seeing in the Store | No. Was It Sold? - In Bulk, 10 lb. Sack, Can Etc. | Ask You Usually Bought at One Time Price of This Amount |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------|
| Soda biscuits         | 1897                                    | Bulk                                             | 1 lb.                                                  |
| Macaroni              | 1891                                    | Bulk                                             | 1 lb. :05                                               |
| Graham flour          | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Brown sugar           | 1897                                    | mostly maple sugar used - we made it             |                                                        |
| Molasses              | 1897                                    | Bulk                                             | 1 qt. 10                                               |
| Table salt            | 1897                                    | Corn in barrel                                  |                                                        |
| Common salt           |                                         |                                                  |                                                        |
| Lily white syrup      |                                         |                                                  |                                                        |
| Toilet soap           | 1906                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Baking powder         | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Baking soda           | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Dried peas            | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Dried corn            |                                         |                                                  |                                                        |
| Vinegar               |                                         |                                                  |                                                        |
| Raisins - seeded      | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
|                       | seedless                                |                                                  |                                                        |
| Rice                  | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Currents              | 1897                                    |                                                  |                                                        |
| Store jam - kinds?    |                                         |                                                  |                                                        |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | | | |
| Vanilla               | 1906                                    |                                                  |                                                        |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Yeast cakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter?

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Baking soda?

Cream of tartar? Did you make your own baking powder?

Yes

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use?

Did you make yeast for your own use?

Using hops?

Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder?

Crust of tart?

Did you take your own baking powder?
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon         | 1896                                   |                              |                                               |
| Canned sardines       | 1891                                   |                              |                                               |
| Other canned fish (not prepared early) - give names |                          |                              |                                               |

| Minute tapioca        |                                        |                              |                                               |

| Dates                 | 1910                                   |                              |                                               |
| Walnuts               |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Icing sugar           | 1915                                   |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

How did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well ...

How far was this water from your home? ... near yard ...

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... pails ...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
12. WHERE DID YOU GET WATER FOR DRINKING AND FOR COOKING? (C.M., RIVER, SLUSH, DUGOUT)

IF OR WAS THIS WATER FROM YOUR HOME?

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)

IF OR WAS IT BROUGHT TO THE HOME? (PAIL, BARREL, TANK)
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ...make own...
If you made your own, did you use lye? .......... used ashes? woodashes
What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Brown All Purpose

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? .......... wood
Where did you get your fuel? ....Mt. More Mountains

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When we were able to cut wood on our own farm in about the year 1919.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ................................................................

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ..............

By whom was your first cook stove made? McClary's
What year was it purchased? 1897 Price? $65.00

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ...........

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) .............

When did you first see enamel ware? 1897

Aluminum? 1897
6.

13. 

Did you buy lumber shop or make your own? 
If yes, would you say it was hard work? 
If yes, could you have bought it from someone else? 
If yes, who would you have bought it from?

14. 

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? 
Was there any chance in the use of fuels which have been taken away since then? 
First started to heat by fireplaces, probably in the late 1800s. 
We moved into our own farm in about the year 1919.

15. 

What type of cooking did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead) 
For preparing food? (Glass, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) 
When did you first use natural sugar? 
Aluminum? 

1997

1897
18. **SNAPPING AND CONTAINERS**

Describe any changes which you recall in the packaging and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

*They had brown paper.*

---

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

*Breakfast: Potatoes, Blood sausage or other sausage, bread, butter, tea, honey. In winter or summer.*
*Dinner: Potatoes, meat, peas. Lot mutton used, puddings (welded rag).*
*Supper: Potatoes, meat, cake.*

---

18. What was served at your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

*Roast Duck, Potatoes, Mac.*
*Plum Pudding.*
*Lemon Pie.*
*Grandma Davis were in the 50s.*
*Rose Lee & Art.*
*18 yrs, 25 yrs, 21 yrs.*

---

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

*No not after grown but when we were little children our ration was scarce. I never saw white sugar till I was 15 years old.*
They had brown people.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. (Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time.) Include the approximate month, etc., weather or season.

Buckwheat Potatoes, Blod sausage and tomato sauce.

Chowder (Potato) meat stew (not potatoes used).

Pudding (chocolate or apple)

Supper Potage, meat cobs.

18. Tell when you served your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kentucky.

Prairie Creek Potatoes & Rice

Plum Pudding

Lemon Pie

Grandfather's old recipe

Rose Liao & Co.

1892 25 yr 21 yr

19. How did you feel when you moved to almost starvation level living on one or two local / regional foods? (Give details.)

We not often grown but when we were total children our nation was ours.

I never saw white sugar till I was 15 years old.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].
